text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 68T45 68T05 68U05 transformations; stel models; Bayesian model; colour-invariant admixture model book article Chua, Jeroen C.; Givoni, Inmar E.; Adams, Ryan P. Number: 1251.68265 Bayesian painting by numbers: flexible priors for colour-invariant object recognition. 2013 Summary: Generative models of images should take into account transformations of geometry and reflectance. Then, they can provide explanations of images that are factorized into intrinsic properties that are useful for subsequent tasks, such as object classification. It was previously shown how images and objects within images could be described as compositions of regions called structural elements or ‘stels’. In this way, transformations of the reflectance and illumination of object parts could be accounted for using a hidden variable that is used to ‘paint’ the same stel differently in different images. For example, the stel corresponding to the petals of a flower can be red in one image and yellow in another. Previous stel models have used a fixed number of stels per image and per image class. Here, we introduce a Bayesian stel model, the colour-invariant admixture (CIA) model, which can infer different numbers of stels for different object types, as appropriate. Results on Caltech101 images show that this method is capable of automatically selecting a number of stels that reflects the complexity of the object class and that these stels are useful for object recognition.

math.1: <m:math xmlns="http://zentralblatt.org" alttext="\Gamma" xml:id="m1.1" display="inline" xref="m1.1.cmml"><m:semantics xml:id="m1.1a" xref="m1.1.cmml"><m:mi mathvariant="normal" xml:id="m1.1.1" xref="m1.1.1.cmml">Γ</m:mi><m:annotation-xml xml:id="m1.1.cmml" encoding="MathML-Content" xref="m1.1"><m:ci xml:id="m1.1.1.cmml" xref="m1.1.1">normal-Γ</m:ci></m:annotation-xml><m:annotation xml:id="m1.1b" encoding="application/x-tex" xref="m1.1.cmml">\Gamma</m:annotation></m:semantics></m:math>

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 94A08 variable exponent; existence of minimizers; image restoration serial article Harjulehto, P.; Hästö, P.; Latvala, V.; Toivanen, O. Number: 6106996 Critical variable exponent functionals in image restoration. 2013 Summary: We study a variable exponent model for image restoration in the case that the exponent attains the critical value one. We prove existence and math1 -convergence. The results answer an open question by Li, Li and Pi [F. Li, Z. Li, L. Pi, Ling, Variable exponent functionals in image restoration, Appl. Math. Comput. 216 (3) (2010) 870 – 882]

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 65N15 65N30 35J25 65N12 mixed finite element; nonconforming finite element; error estimates; low-regularity; second order equation; low-regularity exact solutions; convergence serial article Li, Mingxia; Mao, Shipeng Number: 6106991 A new a priori error analysis of nonconforming and mixed finite element methods. 2013 Summary: We derive an a priori error analysis for the lowest order nonconforming and mixed finite element discretizations of a second order equation with low-regularity exact solutions only, belonging to math1 with math2 . Furthermore, a robust convergence is proved even if the solution is exactly in math3 .

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 30C45 15B05 15A15 analytic function; subordination; Schwarz function; Toeplitz determinants; second Hankel determinant serial article Bansal, Deepak Number: 1250.30006 Upper bound of second Hankel determinant for a new class of analytic functions. 2013 Summary: In the present investigation an upper bound for the second Hankel determinant math1 for functions belonging to the class math2 is studied using Toeplitz determinants.

html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 74-02 74Rxx 76S99 book Adler, Pierre M.; Thovert, Jean-François; Mourzenko, Valeri V. Number: 6110078 Fractured porous media. 2013 Preliminary review / Publisher’s description: This book provides a systematic treatment of the geometrical and transport properties of fractures, fracture networks, and fractured porous media. It is divided into two major parts. The first part deals with geometry of individual fractures and of fracture networks. The use of the dimensionless density rationalizes the results for the percolation threshold of the networks. It presents the crucial advantage of grouping the numerical data for various fracture shapes. The second part deals mainly with permeability under steady conditions of fractures, fracture networks, and fractured porous media. Again the results for various types of networks can be rationalized by means of the dimensionless density. A chapter is dedicated to two phase flow in fractured porous media.

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 11T22 complete mappings; cyclotomic numbers; cyclotomy; orthomorphisms; queens solutions; strong complete mappings serial article Bell, Jordan Number: 6109951 Cyclotomic orthomorphisms of finite fields. 2013 Summary: In this paper, we give explicit formulas for the number of cyclotomic orthomorphisms of math1 of index 3,4,5,6 for certain classes of prime powers math2 . We also give an explicit formula for the number of cyclotomic mappings of index 2 that are strong complete mappings of math3 for prime math4 .

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 74F05 74S30 35Q74 structural stability; convergence result; thermoelasticity of type III serial article Liu, Yan; Lin, Yiwu; Li, Yuanfei Number: 1252.74014 Convergence result for the thermoelasticity of type III. 2013 Summary: The convergence result for the thermoelasticity of type III defined on a semi-infinite cylindrical region is studied. We prove the convergence result for the thermal conductivity math1 .

html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 53C17 53D10 sub-Riemannian geometry; contact geometry; isoperimetric regions; isoperimetric profile; Carnot-Carathéodory distance serial article Galli, Matteo; Ritoré, Manuel Number: 6109993 Existence of isoperimetric regions in contact sub-Riemannian manifolds. 2013 Summary: We prove existence of regions minimizing perimeter under a volume constraint in contact sub-Riemannian manifolds whose quotient by the group of contact transformations preserving the sub-Riemannian metric is compact.

html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 62-07 00A71 62P99 book von Eye, Alexander; Mun, Eun-Young Number: 6108248 Log-linear modeling. Concepts, interpretation and application. 2013 Preliminary review / Publisher’s description: Highlighting advances that have lent to the topic’s distinct, coherent methodology over the past decade, Log-Linear Modeling: Concepts, Interpretation, and Application provides an essential, introductory treatment of the subject, featuring many new and advanced log-linear methods, models, and applications. The book begins with basic coverage of categorical data, and goes on to describe the basics of hierarchical log-linear models as well as decomposing effects in cross-classifications and goodness-of-fit tests. Additional topics include: – The generalized linear model (GLM) along with popular methods of coding such as effect coding and dummy coding – Parameter interpretation and how to ensure that the parameters reflect the hypotheses being studied – Symmetry, rater agreement, homogeneity of association, logistic regression, and reduced designs models Throughout the book, real-world data illustrate the application of models and understanding of the related results. In addition, each chapter utilizes R, SYSTAT, and âEM software, providing readers with an understanding of these programs in the context of hierarchical log-linear modeling. Log-Linear Modeling is an excellent book for courses on categorical data analysis at the upper-undergraduate and graduate levels. It also serves as an excellent reference for applied researchers in virtually any area of study, from medicine and statistics to the social sciences, who analyze empirical data in their everyday work.
